JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 4.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 3, 1913.

HOPKINS LOSES TO SWARTHMORE

MANY LECTURES TO BE HELD
Dr. Sato of Japan to Come — Alliance
Francaise and Archaeologists to
Meet in McCoy Hall.

Dr. Shostike Sato, dean of the
College of Agriculture in the Tohake Imperial University, Sapporo,
Japan, will deliver a series of lectures here early in the winter. Dr.
Sato will come to this country as
the second lecturer on the Japanese Exchange Foundation, established in 1912 between the following Seven universities: Hopkins,
.Columbia, Brown, Virginia, Minnesota, North Carolina and Illinois.
Dr. Sato received the degree of
doctor of philosophy from Hopkins
and has the distinction of having
been a classmate of President
Woodrow Wilson. He is one of
the most distinguished educators of
Japan, and was chosen by the colleges of his country to represent
them here. The purpose of the
Exchange Foundation, under which
he is to come here, is to bring
Japan and the United States closer
together by teaching the young men
of each country the customs, institutions and history of the other.
The first lecturer on this Foundation was Dr. Inazo Nitobe, of the
University of Tokyo, and also the
holder of a Ph. D. degree from ,
Hopkins.
Dr. Nitobe was here in February, I912,• at which time he delivered a series of seven lectures.
The lectures were so well attended
that McCoy Hall was taxed beyond
capacity and Dr. Nitobe concluded
the series in the Academy of Music
Concert Hall.
Dr. Sato is a man of broad
education and culture. After his
graduation from Hopkins, in '86,
he studied for several years in Germany before returning to his native
country. He is well known as a
scholar in Europe and America and
is the master of English and several
Continental languages.
The first of the annual series of
lectures held under the auspices of
the Baltimore Section of the Alliance Francaise, of which Dr. Murray P. Brush is secretary, will be
heard on Saturday, November 8, at
T2 o'clock, in McCoy Hall, when
M. Jean Ducros speaks on "La
Poesie Apres les Romantiques."
Membership i n t Ii e Alliance
Francaise is open to students of the
University by. the payment of a
nominal fee. The lectures are delivered in French, and , embrace
many subjects of interest pertaining to French literature, art and
science.

Here are the songs and yells to be voted for adoption by the cheering section. The
winner of the song contest is to receive five dollars, and the winner of the yell contest, three dollars. Each student is entitled .to one vote.
The songs and yells will be rehearsed Wednesday at one o'clock in Hopkins
Hall at the regular weekly yell practice.
Song No. 1—FIELD SONG.
Air: Ballard's "Stein Song."
When Fortune smiles no longer, and our chance looks rather black,
When the foe grows ever stronger, and our line is falling back;
Then we'll stand by the banner in the old Johns Hopkins manner
And cheer till the echo comes ringing, singing back:
Johns Hopkins to the field then! Stand fast and never yield then!
— We will fight till they down us, and rise and fight again!
Her name is ours to honor, we will scorn defeat and ill;
The Black and Blue forever! In loss or gain—fight still!
For her strong sons who bore it, who gave their manhood for it,
They call us to follow, and guard the flag we will!
Johns Hopkins to the field then! Stand fast and never yield then!
We will fight till they down us, and rise and fight again!

The Varsity Displays Form and Is Barely
Defeated in a Hard-Fought Battle
by the Score of 10 to 7.

Displaying more form than it has
at any time this season, the Hopkins football team was barely defeated by Swarthmore Saturday at
Homewood, the score being 10 to 7.
The contest w as a first-class one
from beginning to end; and, judging by the way Hopkins played, the
remaining games should result in
much success for the Black and
Blue.
Hopkins seemed to have found itself. The men held together, fought
hard, and made every play count.
The line held like a stone wall; at
no time was Swarthmore able to
make more than a few yards by
plunging, and when the superior
weight of the Swarthmore team is
considered, this feature seems all
the more remarkable.
Tippett and Bowers were the stars
for Hopkins. Both played a consistent game, Tippett scoring the
touchdown which tied the score in
the second period.
Captain Leibensperger, Wilkinson and Fulton were also mainstays
of the team.
The first touchdown was made by
Swarthmore about the middle of the
first quarter. After the kickoff,
Hopkins to Swarthmore, Swarthmore punted. Both teams tried forward passes, failing each time.
Hopkins punted, and Swarthmore
worked the ball up the field by forward passes and end runs. Then,
on a pass, MacKessick to Durburow, the right end ran from the 30yard line through a clear field for
a touchdown. AfacKessick kicked
goal. Later ;n the period Branham
caught a forward pass and was
downed on the 7-yald line, just as
the quarter ended, but at the beginning of the next, Hopkins lost the
ball on a fumble, missing an excellent chance to score.
Directly f9llowing, MacKissick
punted, Tippett gained five yards
through the line, and then took
the ball on a 30-yard run to the
goal. Wilkinson kicked, making
the score 7 to 7.
In the third qtiarter Swarthmore
was unable to gain through Hopkins line. Towards the middle of
the period MacKissick pulled off
a long forward pass to Howell,
after which more passes placed the
ball on Hopkins 20-yard line. MacKissick then drop-kicked goal, winning the game for Swarthmore, 10
to 7.
In the fourth period there was
little gained on line plays by either

GRACIOUS "GROW-SHOUS!"

DEBATING COUNCIL IS ACTIVE

First Meeting of the Grotius Society
Held in Donovan Room—Cliff Wells
Embroiled in Suffragist Problem.

Will Hold Triangular Debate With U. of
Va.,and North Carolina—Considering Contest With C. C.of N.Y.

The Grotius Society met last Tuesday, at one o'clock, in the Donovan
Room with an attendance of about
fifteen, including several freshmen.
The first-year men are especially invited to join the society. There are
no requirements or qualifications;
merely attend, give your name to
the secretary and your dollar to the
treasurer! Nothing of very great
importance was done, but various
plans of procedure during the present year were discussed. It was
eventually decided to select some
interesting topic, as closely allied
as possible to the thoughts of the
members, and to discuss, in an informal way, this subject at the next
meeting. Mr. Wells, '14, was appointed to open the discussion next
week upon woman suffrage. He
will support the opposition side and
will be t eady to refute the arguments of the adherents of "votes
for women." This next meeting
will be held on Tuesday, at one
o'clock, in the Donovan Room.

At the last meeting of the Debating Council, plans for this year
were formulated.
A triangular debate will be held,
in which Hopkins, Virginia and
North Carolina will be the contestants. Each university will send
teams to the other two colleges, so
that each team will be debating on
neutral ground. There was some
discussion over placing Hopkins in
another triangle with colleges like
Princeton and Columbia, but it was
found that the schedules of all the
big Northern colleges had already
been completed.
As the triangle in which Hopkins is entered, however, is one of
the most important in the South,the
Black and Blue orators will be kept
busy enough. The council is considering a dual debate with the City
College of New York, which was
met two years ago, but the matter
has not been definitely arranged.
The regular interclass debate, between the seniors and juniors, will
be held early next spring in conjunction with the sophomore public
speaking contest.

Charles C. Adams, M. D. '04, is
at the Rockefeller Institute, N. Y.

Tim NEws-LETTER passes over,
without comment,the recent football
fiasco, but will have something to
say of the entire athletic situation
in a later issue.
The Swarthmore Game.

Although defeated Saturday by
the narrow margin of three points,
the team showed a "come-back"
- which surpassed the expectations
of the most optimistic. The sure
tackling and dogged defense against
the Garnet aggregation, forcing
Swarthmore to kick when a touchdown seemed imminent, were all
evidences of the new spirit which
has infused itself into the team.
The apathy ::hown in former contests has been completely wiped out.
Medical student and undergraduate
worked as a unit for Black and
Blue. But TIIE NEWS-LETTER does
not propose to play the side-line
coach, and will leave any criticism
of the team, good or bad, to the
coaches.
To the rooters, however, a few
words are in order. First, that
Saturday's cheering compared favorably with any that has ever been
heard at Homewood.
The short, snappy, yells, introduced for the first time, were a distinct success and should be continued. Indeed, the rooters sometimes yelled to) much. That is they
yelled sq continuously as to have no
voice for crucial moments. And
sometimes when Sutton started a
cheer, everybody became so interested in the game as to let the
cheer die in mid air. Don't let's
start anything next Saturday that
we can't finish.
Second, concerning courtesy to
the visting team: when Swarthmore
was trying the "Straus" formation,
such a din arose as to keep our opponents from hearing their quarterback. Fortunately the yelling sub-

enced American literature, are the

the Bible has influenced the literature of the mother country in

That the Bible is of inestimable

The Bishop of London ably refutes
this unfounded yet common conjecture. "Teaching members of the
Royal Society and the British Association are earnest Christians," he
says. "So far from their being increasing unbelief amongst the leading men of learning, it is just the
other way. There is quite a reaction towards earnest belief in Christ.
Mr. Gladstone and Lord Salisbury
both died in perfect trust in Jesus."

literary, practical, and spiritual importance cannot be studied at the

It remains for the students to

THE NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 3, 1913.

SCHLOSS THE WINNER

DR. HOGUE MEETS BIBLE CLASS

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

"Cupid," the Pants King, Wins Privilege
to Accompany Miss Prowler's Charming Charges—Plenty of Excitement.

First Lesson in "Manhood of the Master"
to Come Thursday—An Unusual
Opportunity for Study.

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

"Cupid- Schloss, pants king, the
popula'r junior, won the position at
St. Timothy's last Thursday, which
was decided by drawing lots, according to the announcement in last
week's issue of THE NEWS-LETTER.
Owing to the excitement created
among the large number of candidates present, the drawing was held
behind the 1 ocked doors of the
chapel. "Bod" Wagner, telling THE
NEWS-LETTER reporter of the lottery, spoke as follows:
"Sure we held the drawing—sure.
There were about forty men waiting out there, and that excitement
sure was intense. I put the chances
into my hat and let 'em draw.
Three of the men who drew blanks
fainted—sure. After all the lots
wei e drawn, Schloss came • tip,
trembling with excitement, and
showed me his slip; it sure was the
winner. He sure did get some congratulations.
"The rest of that bunch sure did
look blue. They sure did look at
Schloss with envious glances as
they slowly passed out of the door.
I got in touch with Miss Prowler
and sent Schloss out to see her. She
sure did like him. Why,she thought
so much of him that she gave him
charge of an extra class in equestrienne training. What do you think
of that. Yes, sir; she sure did."
Mr. Schloss acknowledged• his
pleasure at securing the position.
"I am an ardent advocate of the
'feminist movement,'"he said, "and
never enjoy myself more than when
in the company of young people."
"Yes," he went on, "I have made
some radical changes in my course,
and am now taking physics and
natural history.
"My weight does bother me
slightly, but Professor Doyle and
rolling are taking care of that.
"I'm having trouble in securing
a suitable horse," he replied when
questioned about the equestrienne
am in touch with Mr.
training.
C. L. Stotesbary and am considering his hunter, `Fastashell! Mr.
John Fife Slymington of F has
also requested me to look over his
stables."
"I hope we are not going to lose
you from the cheering section on
Saturdays." timidly asked the freshman reporter. "No, indeed; why
I've arranged with the school authorities to secure two dozen seats
right next to the cheering section,
so I'll combine business with pleasure. But," he broke in hastily,
"Professor Doyle is waiting; come
see me again."

The first meeting of the Rev. Mr.
Richard W. Hogue's Bible Class on
"The Manhood of the Master" took
place last Thursday, at one o'clock,
in Levering Hall. All those who
attended this initial meeting were
enthusiastic over the class and the
leader. The Rev. Mr. Hogue is
a man who has the broadest sympathy for college men, being a college man himself. He attended the
University of the South for his undergraduate and theological training, and work of several years'
duration among the students of the
University of North Carolina at
Chapel Hill, make him particularly
suited to lead and understand the
average undergraduate.
The meeting last Thursday was
introductory. The Rev. Mr. Hogue
explained forcibly and intellectually
the necessity of every college man
having an accurate and detailed
knowledge of the life and works of
Christ. Next Thursday will be devoted to the first study in H. E.
Fosdick's "Manhood of the Master," and it is hoped that all who
have not yet joined this class will
not let slip so unusual an opportunity to learn the fundamental
facts of Christianity from the broad
outlook of Rev. Mr. Hogue's teaching.

Lieut. F. Van Vleck, of the
Maryland Naval Reserves, enrolled
at Hopkins in '84 and '85 as a
graduate student in history, sailed
with the North Atlantic Fleet for
Southern European ports on Saturday, November 1.

OCTOBER 22, 1913.
THE NEWS-LETTER:

To the Editor of

Dear Sir—If suggestions are not
unacceptable to you, and to all
whom this may concern, I venture
to present one, begging that you
will give it the means of making itself heard through your columns.
It has occurred to me, and doubtless to many other thirsters after
general knowledge and information,
that the present method of bringing the announcements and communications of the various authorities to the notice of the students
is hindered a great deal in its effectiveness by the number of "back
numbers" which constantly crowd
out the up-to-date matters. It is
practically impossible for the casual
surveyor to add anything to his
knowledge of the duties intended
to be urged upon him by the notices,
and even the determined searcher
must strive with dogged pertinacity
to discover anything of interest
among that vast host of last week's
excitements.
I should like to suggest to those
who feel sufficient responsibility in

such matters to care to strive for
improvement, a system that might
possibly be effective in setting before the readers only such notices
as are of up-to-date importance.
If every notice placed upon the
field of public vision should bear at
its head two dates, that upon which
it was posted, for the convenience
of its readers, and that upon which
its services would be no longer required, and then every knowledgeseeker would add to the list of his
college duties which he performs
unfailingly with the most scrupulous rigidity, the duty of always
removing from the public eye any
notices whose second date was past,
the bulletin board Would then set
forth a concentrated essence of vital
communications, every word of
which was of present importance,
and its duty would be accomplished
with ten—yea,a hundred-fold force.

do well to pay marked attention when

And the maiden answered quick;
"I think it quite likely you're right—

Eight Tome Men in Club.

The Tome Society, which shares
with the Engineering Society the
honor of being the youngest in the
University, has a membership of
eight this year—an increase of one
over last year. Two members were
lost—the Hon. G. E. Porter, by
graduation, and P. A. Hall, who left
the University. Three members of
the freshman class have joined the
society. They are: Smith, Webb
and Hall. The officers of the society are Bagley, president, and
Leitheiser, secretary-treasurer. The
other members are Courtney and
Rutledge.
The society is of a social nature,
its purpose being to hold together
by a fraternal bond, those graduates
of Tome School who conic to Hopkins. This purpose is accomplished
by the holding of monthly "feeds,"
theatre parties and entertainments.

"No wine at the senior banquet"
is the recent dictum of the senior
class of Cornell University by a
vote of 295 to 213. By a second
vote of 276 to 232 the class has
voted to bar intoxicants from all
the class functions save two—the
senior boat ride and senior night.
This action comes largely as the result of a persistent campaign of the
University Prohibition League to
abate students' drinking customs.
Do you know that Maine, often
held up as an example of "prohibition don't prohibit," has a per capita
consumption of only $1.42 as against
$17.39 in the whole United States?"
"The closing of saloons automatically results in the closing of
houses of prostitution," declared
Dr. R. 0. Moody of the anatomy
department of the University of
California in a recent lecture in the
department of education.
"The fraternity which rushes you
via the saloon route, or the Barbary
Coast, is not the bunch to join, because they aren't in themselves true
Californians, and we don't want
either of them of any more of their
kind," declares President Wheeler
of the University of California.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 4.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 3, 1913.

HOPKINS LOSES TO SWARTHMORE

MANY LECTURES TO BE HELD
Dr. Sato of Japan to Come — Alliance
Francaise and Archaeologists to
Meet in McCoy Hall.

Dr. Shostike Sato, dean of the
College of Agriculture in the Tohake Imperial University, Sapporo,
Japan, will deliver a series of lectures here early in the winter. Dr.
Sato will come to this country as
the second lecturer on the Japanese Exchange Foundation, established in 1912 between the following Seven universities: Hopkins,
.Columbia, Brown, Virginia, Minnesota, North Carolina and Illinois.
Dr. Sato received the degree of
doctor of philosophy from Hopkins
and has the distinction of having
been a classmate of President
Woodrow Wilson. He is one of
the most distinguished educators of
Japan, and was chosen by the colleges of his country to represent
them here. The purpose of the
Exchange Foundation, under which
he is to come here, is to bring
Japan and the United States closer
together by teaching the young men
of each country the customs, institutions and history of the other.
The first lecturer on this Foundation was Dr. Inazo Nitobe, of the
University of Tokyo, and also the
holder of a Ph. D. degree from ,
Hopkins.
Dr. Nitobe was here in February, I912,• at which time he delivered a series of seven lectures.
The lectures were so well attended
that McCoy Hall was taxed beyond
capacity and Dr. Nitobe concluded
the series in the Academy of Music
Concert Hall.
Dr. Sato is a man of broad
education and culture. After his
graduation from Hopkins, in '86,
he studied for several years in Germany before returning to his native
country. He is well known as a
scholar in Europe and America and
is the master of English and several
Continental languages.
The first of the annual series of
lectures held under the auspices of
the Baltimore Section of the Alliance Francaise, of which Dr. Murray P. Brush is secretary, will be
heard on Saturday, November 8, at
T2 o'clock, in McCoy Hall, when
M. Jean Ducros speaks on "La
Poesie Apres les Romantiques."
Membership i n t Ii e Alliance
Francaise is open to students of the
University by. the payment of a
nominal fee. The lectures are delivered in French, and , embrace
many subjects of interest pertaining to French literature, art and
science.

The Varsity Displays Form and Is Barely
Defeated in a Hard-Fought Battle
by the Score of 10 to 7.

Displaying more form than it has
at any time this season, the Hopkins football team was barely defeated by Swarthmore Saturday at
Homewood, the score being 10 to 7.
The contest w as a first-class one
from beginning to end; and, judging by the way Hopkins played, the
remaining games should result in
much success for the Black and
Blue.
Hopkins seemed to have found itself. The men held together, fought
hard, and made every play count.
The line held like a stone wall; at
no time was Swarthmore able to
make more than a few yards by
plunging, and when the superior
weight of the Swarthmore team is
considered, this feature seems all
the more remarkable.
Tippett and Bowers were the stars
for Hopkins. Both played a consistent game, Tippett scoring the
touchdown which tied the score in
the second period.
Captain Leibensperger, Wilkinson and Fulton were also mainstays
of the team.
The first touchdown was made by
Swarthmore about the middle of the
first quarter. After the kickoff,
Hopkins to Swarthmore, Swarthmore punted. Both teams tried forward passes, failing each time.
Hopkins punted, and Swarthmore
worked the ball up the field by forward passes and end runs. Then,
on a pass, MacKessick to Durburow, the right end ran from the 30yard line through a clear field for
a touchdown. AfacKessick kicked
goal. Later ;n the period Branham
caught a forward pass and was
downed on the 7-yald line, just as
the quarter ended, but at the beginning of the next, Hopkins lost the
ball on a fumble, missing an excellent chance to score.
Directly f9llowing, MacKissick
punted, Tippett gained five yards
through the line, and then took
the ball on a 30-yard run to the
goal. Wilkinson kicked, making
the score 7 to 7.
In the third qtiarter Swarthmore
was unable to gain through Hopkins line. Towards the middle of
the period MacKissick pulled off
a long forward pass to Howell,
after which more passes placed the
ball on Hopkins 20-yard line. MacKissick then drop-kicked goal, winning the game for Swarthmore, 10
to 7.
In the fourth period there was
little gained on line plays by either

GRACIOUS "GROW-SHOUS!"

DEBATING COUNCIL IS ACTIVE

First Meeting of the Grotius Society
Held in Donovan Room—Cliff Wells
Embroiled in Suffragist Problem.

Will Hold Triangular Debate With U. of
Va.,and North Carolina—Considering Contest With C. C.of N.Y.

The Grotius Society met last Tuesday, at one o'clock, in the Donovan
Room with an attendance of about
fifteen, including several freshmen.
The first-year men are especially invited to join the society. There are
no requirements or qualifications;
merely attend, give your name to
the secretary and your dollar to the
treasurer! Nothing of very great
importance was done, but various
plans of procedure during the present year were discussed. It was
eventually decided to select some
interesting topic, as closely allied
as possible to the thoughts of the
members, and to discuss, in an informal way, this subject at the next
meeting. Mr. Wells, '14, was appointed to open the discussion next
week upon woman suffrage. He
will support the opposition side and
will be t eady to refute the arguments of the adherents of "votes
for women." This next meeting
will be held on Tuesday, at one
o'clock, in the Donovan Room.

At the last meeting of the Debating Council, plans for this year
were formulated.
A triangular debate will be held,
in which Hopkins, Virginia and
North Carolina will be the contestants. Each university will send
teams to the other two colleges, so
that each team will be debating on
neutral ground. There was some
discussion over placing Hopkins in
another triangle with colleges like
Princeton and Columbia, but it was
found that the schedules of all the
big Northern colleges had already
been completed.
As the triangle in which Hopkins is entered, however, is one of
the most important in the South,the
Black and Blue orators will be kept
busy enough. The council is considering a dual debate with the City
College of New York, which was
met two years ago, but the matter
has not been definitely arranged.
The regular interclass debate, between the seniors and juniors, will
be held early next spring in conjunction with the sophomore public
speaking contest.

Charles C. Adams, M. D. '04, is
at the Rockefeller Institute, N. Y.

Tim NEws-LETTER passes over,
without comment,the recent football
fiasco, but will have something to
say of the entire athletic situation
in a later issue.
The Swarthmore Game.

Although defeated Saturday by
the narrow margin of three points,
the team showed a "come-back"
- which surpassed the expectations
of the most optimistic. The sure
tackling and dogged defense against
the Garnet aggregation, forcing
Swarthmore to kick when a touchdown seemed imminent, were all
evidences of the new spirit which
has infused itself into the team.
The apathy ::hown in former contests has been completely wiped out.
Medical student and undergraduate
worked as a unit for Black and
Blue. But TIIE NEWS-LETTER does
not propose to play the side-line
coach, and will leave any criticism
of the team, good or bad, to the
coaches.
To the rooters, however, a few
words are in order. First, that
Saturday's cheering compared favorably with any that has ever been
heard at Homewood.
The short, snappy, yells, introduced for the first time, were a distinct success and should be continued. Indeed, the rooters sometimes yelled to) much. That is they
yelled sq continuously as to have no
voice for crucial moments. And
sometimes when Sutton started a
cheer, everybody became so interested in the game as to let the
cheer die in mid air. Don't let's
start anything next Saturday that
we can't finish.
Second, concerning courtesy to
the visting team: when Swarthmore
was trying the "Straus" formation,
such a din arose as to keep our opponents from hearing their quarterback. Fortunately the yelling sub-

enced American literature, are the

and the English common law, and
the Bible has influenced the literature of the mother country in
exactly the same way. A man who
doesn't know his Bible cannot claim
familiarity with English literature.
And the Bible is a mighty force
outside the realms of literature.
Their Biblical origin is what made
so forceful Bryan's "Crucified on
a Cross of Gold," and Roosevelt's
"We Stand at Armageddon." How
much stronger is some "devil" of
a lawyer, "quoting Scripture to his

day, and a contentious woman are
much alike !"
That the Bible is of inestimable
value in spiritual development goes
without saying. "Search the Scriptures, for they testify of me." Yet
on this very account some men refuse to study their Bible. They
think that to be men of science and
learning, they must be atheists
The Bishop of London ably refutes
this unfounded yet common conjecture. "Teaching members of the
Royal Society and the British Association are earnest Christians," he
says. "So far from their being increasing unbelief amongst the leading men of learning, it is just the
other way. There is quite a reaction towards earnest belief in Christ.
Mr. Gladstone and Lord Salisbury
both died in perfect trust in Jesus."

literary, practical, and spiritual importance cannot be studied at the

endless controversy. In denominational colleges alone can the Bible
be studied without friction.

meet this want. In Dr. Hogue and
Dr. Swartz, the two able leaders
of the Bible classes, the Association
has most successfully met the need.
It remains for the students to
seize their opportunity.

THE NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 3, 1913.

SCHLOSS THE WINNER

DR. HOGUE MEETS BIBLE CLASS

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

"Cupid," the Pants King, Wins Privilege
to Accompany Miss Prowler's Charming Charges—Plenty of Excitement.

First Lesson in "Manhood of the Master"
to Come Thursday—An Unusual
Opportunity for Study.

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

"Cupid- Schloss, pants king, the
popula'r junior, won the position at
St. Timothy's last Thursday, which
was decided by drawing lots, according to the announcement in last
week's issue of THE NEWS-LETTER.
Owing to the excitement created
among the large number of candidates present, the drawing was held
behind the 1 ocked doors of the
chapel. "Bod" Wagner, telling THE
NEWS-LETTER reporter of the lottery, spoke as follows:
"Sure we held the drawing—sure.
There were about forty men waiting out there, and that excitement
sure was intense. I put the chances
into my hat and let 'em draw.
Three of the men who drew blanks
fainted—sure. After all the lots
wei e drawn, Schloss came • tip,
trembling with excitement, and
showed me his slip; it sure was the
winner. He sure did get some congratulations.
"The rest of that bunch sure did
look blue. They sure did look at
Schloss with envious glances as
they slowly passed out of the door.
I got in touch with Miss Prowler
and sent Schloss out to see her. She
sure did like him. Why,she thought
so much of him that she gave him
charge of an extra class in equestrienne training. What do you think
of that. Yes, sir; she sure did."
Mr. Schloss acknowledged• his
pleasure at securing the position.
"I am an ardent advocate of the
'feminist movement,'"he said, "and
never enjoy myself more than when
in the company of young people."
"Yes," he went on, "I have made
some radical changes in my course,
and am now taking physics and
natural history.
"My weight does bother me
slightly, but Professor Doyle and
rolling are taking care of that.
"I'm having trouble in securing
a suitable horse," he replied when
questioned about the equestrienne
am in touch with Mr.
training.
C. L. Stotesbary and am considering his hunter, `Fastashell! Mr.
John Fife Slymington of F has
also requested me to look over his
stables."
"I hope we are not going to lose
you from the cheering section on
Saturdays." timidly asked the freshman reporter. "No, indeed; why
I've arranged with the school authorities to secure two dozen seats
right next to the cheering section,
so I'll combine business with pleasure. But," he broke in hastily,
"Professor Doyle is waiting; come
see me again."

The first meeting of the Rev. Mr.
Richard W. Hogue's Bible Class on
"The Manhood of the Master" took
place last Thursday, at one o'clock,
in Levering Hall. All those who
attended this initial meeting were
enthusiastic over the class and the
leader. The Rev. Mr. Hogue is
a man who has the broadest sympathy for college men, being a college man himself. He attended the
University of the South for his undergraduate and theological training, and work of several years'
duration among the students of the
University of North Carolina at
Chapel Hill, make him particularly
suited to lead and understand the
average undergraduate.
The meeting last Thursday was
introductory. The Rev. Mr. Hogue
explained forcibly and intellectually
the necessity of every college man
having an accurate and detailed
knowledge of the life and works of
Christ. Next Thursday will be devoted to the first study in H. E.
Fosdick's "Manhood of the Master," and it is hoped that all who
have not yet joined this class will
not let slip so unusual an opportunity to learn the fundamental
facts of Christianity from the broad
outlook of Rev. Mr. Hogue's teaching.

Wants Notices Dated.

Lieut. F. Van Vleck, of the
Maryland Naval Reserves, enrolled
at Hopkins in '84 and '85 as a
graduate student in history, sailed
with the North Atlantic Fleet for
Southern European ports on Saturday, November 1.

OCTOBER 22, 1913.
THE NEWS-LETTER:

To the Editor of

Dear Sir—If suggestions are not
unacceptable to you, and to all
whom this may concern, I venture
to present one, begging that you
will give it the means of making itself heard through your columns.
It has occurred to me, and doubtless to many other thirsters after
general knowledge and information,
that the present method of bringing the announcements and communications of the various authorities to the notice of the students
is hindered a great deal in its effectiveness by the number of "back
numbers" which constantly crowd
out the up-to-date matters. It is
practically impossible for the casual
surveyor to add anything to his
knowledge of the duties intended
to be urged upon him by the notices,
and even the determined searcher
must strive with dogged pertinacity
to discover anything of interest
among that vast host of last week's
excitements.
I should like to suggest to those
who feel sufficient responsibility in

such matters to care to strive for
improvement, a system that might
possibly be effective in setting before the readers only such notices
as are of up-to-date importance.
If every notice placed upon the
field of public vision should bear at
its head two dates, that upon which
it was posted, for the convenience
of its readers, and that upon which
its services would be no longer required, and then every knowledgeseeker would add to the list of his
college duties which he performs
unfailingly with the most scrupulous rigidity, the duty of always
removing from the public eye any
notices whose second date was past,
the bulletin board Would then set
forth a concentrated essence of vital
communications, every word of
which was of present importance,
and its duty would be accomplished
with ten—yea,a hundred-fold force.

Eight Tome Men in Club.

The Tome Society, which shares
with the Engineering Society the
honor of being the youngest in the
University, has a membership of
eight this year—an increase of one
over last year. Two members were
lost—the Hon. G. E. Porter, by
graduation, and P. A. Hall, who left
the University. Three members of
the freshman class have joined the
society. They are: Smith, Webb
and Hall. The officers of the society are Bagley, president, and
Leitheiser, secretary-treasurer. The
other members are Courtney and
Rutledge.
The society is of a social nature,
its purpose being to hold together
by a fraternal bond, those graduates
of Tome School who conic to Hopkins. This purpose is accomplished
by the holding of monthly "feeds,"
theatre parties and entertainments.

"No wine at the senior banquet"
is the recent dictum of the senior
class of Cornell University by a
vote of 295 to 213. By a second
vote of 276 to 232 the class has
voted to bar intoxicants from all
the class functions save two—the
senior boat ride and senior night.
This action comes largely as the result of a persistent campaign of the
University Prohibition League to
abate students' drinking customs.
Do you know that Maine, often
held up as an example of "prohibition don't prohibit," has a per capita
consumption of only $1.42 as against
$17.39 in the whole United States?"
"The closing of saloons automatically results in the closing of
houses of prostitution," declared
Dr. R. 0. Moody of the anatomy
department of the University of
California in a recent lecture in the
department of education.
"The fraternity which rushes you
via the saloon route, or the Barbary
Coast, is not the bunch to join, because they aren't in themselves true
Californians, and we don't want
either of them of any more of their
kind," declares President Wheeler
of the University of California.
